00009 def get_from_commandline(option, default=None, argv=sys.argv):
00010     """
00011     Search for option (e.g. '-p', '--plotfile') among the command-line
00012     arguments and return the associated value (the proceeding argument).
00013     If the option is not found, the default argument is returned.
00014 
00015     str2obj(get_from_commandline(option, default=...) will return
00016     a Python object (with the right type) corresponding to the value of
00017     the object (see the str2obj function)-
00018 
00019     @param option: command-line option.
00020     @type  option: string.
00021     @param default: default value associated with this option.
00022     @param argv: list that is scanned for command-line arguments.
00023     @return: the item in argv after the option, or default is option
00024     is not found.
00025 
00026     """
00027     try:
00028         index = argv.index(option)
00029         return argv[index+1]
00030     except ValueError:
00031         return default
00032     except IndexError:
00033         raise IndexError, 'array of command-line arguments is too short; '\
00034               'no value after %s option' % option
00035 
00036 def str2obj(s, globals=globals(), locals=locals()):
00037     """
00038     Turn string s into the corresponding object.
00039     eval(s) normally does this, but if s is just a string ready
00040     from file, GUI or the command-line, eval will not work when
00041     s really represents a string:
00042     >>> eval('some string')
00043     Traceback (most recent call last):
00044     SyntaxError: unexpected EOF while parsing
00045     It tries to parse 'some string' as Python code.
00046 
00047     In this function we try to eval(s), and if it works, we
00048     return that object. If it does not work, s probably has
00049     meaning as a string, and we return just s.
00050 
00051     Examples::
00052     
00053     >>> from misc import str2obj
00054     >>> s = str2obj('0.3')
00055     >>> print s, type(s)
00056     0.3 <type 'float'>
00057     >>> s = str2obj('3')
00058     >>> print s, type(s)
00059     3 <type 'int'>
00060     >>> s = str2obj('(1,8)')
00061     >>> print s, type(s)
00062     (1, 8) <type 'tuple'>
00063     >>> s = str2obj('some string')
00064     >>> s
00065     'some string'
00066 
00067     If the name of a user defined function, class or instance is
00068     sent to str2obj, one must also provide locals() and globals()
00069     dictionaries as extra arguments. Otherwise, str2obj will not
00070     know how to "eval" the string and produce the right object
00071     (user defined types are not known inside str2obj).
00072     Here is an example::
00073     
00074     >>> def myf(x):
00075     ...     return 1+x
00076     ... 
00077     >>> class A:
00078     ...     pass
00079     ... 
00080     >>> a = A()
00081     >>> 
00082     >>> s = str2obj('myf')
00083     >>> print s, type(s)   # now s is simply the string 'myf'
00084     myf <type 'str'>
00085     >>> # provide locals and globals such that we get the function myf:
00086     >>> s = str2obj('myf', locals(), globals())
00087     >>> print s, type(s)
00088     <function myf at 0xb70ffe2c> <type 'function'>
00089     >>> s = str2obj('a', locals(), globals())
00090     >>> print s, type(s)
00091     <__main__.A instance at 0xb70f6fcc> <type 'instance'>
00092 
00093     Caveat: if the string argument is the name of a valid Python
00094     class (type), that class will be returned. For example,
00095     >>> str2obj('list')  # returns class list
00096     <type 'list'>
00097 
00098     You can normally safely apply eval on the output of this function.
00099     """
00100     try:
00101         s = eval(s, globals, locals)
00102         return s
00103     except:
00104         return s
00105

00107 def before(string, character):   
00108     """Return part of string before character."""
00109     for i in range(len(string)):
00110         if c == character:
00111             return string[:i-1]
00112 
00113 def after(string, character):
00114     """Return part of string after character."""
00115     for i in range(len(string)):
00116         if c == character:
00117             return string[i+1:]
00118 
00119 def remove_multiple_items(somelist):
00120     """
00121     Given some list somelist, return a list where identical items
00122     are removed.
00123     """
00124     right_type(somelist, 'somelist', list)
00125     new = []
00126     helphash = {}
00127     for item in somelist:
00128         if not item in helphash:
00129             new.append(item)
00130             helphash[item] = 1
00131     return new

00134 def find(func, rootdir, arg=None):
00135     """
00136     Traverse the directory tree rootdir and call func for each file.
00137     arg is a user-provided argument transferred to func(filename,arg).
00138     """
00139     files = os.listdir(rootdir)  # get all files in rootdir
00140     files.sort(lambda a,b: cmp(a.lower(),b.lower()))
00141     for file in files:
00142         filepath = os.path.join(rootdir,file) # make complete path
00143         if os.path.islink(filepath):
00144             pass # drop links...
00145         elif os.path.isdir(filepath):
00146             find(func, filepath, arg) # recurse into directory
00147         elif os.path.isfile(filepath):
00148             func(filepath, arg) # file is regular, apply func
00149         else:
00150             print 'find: cannot treat ',filepath
00151 
00152 
00153 def sorted_os_path_walk(root, func, arg):
00154     """
00155     Like os.path.walk, but directories and files are visited and
00156     listed in alphabetic order.
00157     """
00158     try:
00159         files = os.listdir(root)  # get all files in rootdir
00160     except os.error:
00161         return
00162     files.sort(lambda a,b: cmp(a.lower(), b.lower()))
00163     func(arg, root, files)
00164     for name in files:
00165         name = os.path.join(root, name)
00166         if os.path.isdir(name):
00167             sorted_os_path_walk(name, func, arg) # recurse into directory

00170 class Command:
00171     """Alternative to lambda functions."""
00172 
00173     def __init__(self, func, *args, **kwargs):
00174         self.funcfunc = func
00175         self.argsargs = args
00176         self.kwargskwargs = kwargs
00177 
00178     def __call__(self, *args, **kwargs):
00179         args = args + self.argsargs
00180         kwargs.update(self.kwargskwargs)  # override kw with orig self.kw
00181         self.funcfunc(*args, **kwargs)

00183 def timer(func, args=[], kwargs={}, repetitions=10, comment=''):
00184     """
00185     Run a function func, with arguments given by the tuple
00186     args and keyword arguments given by the dictionary kwargs,
00187     a specified number of times (repetitions) and
00188     write out the elapsed time and the CPU time together.
00189     """
00190     t0 = time.time();  c0 = time.clock()
00191     for i in range(repetitions):
00192         func(*args, **kwargs)
00193     cpu_time = time.clock()-c0
00194     elapsed_time = time.time()-t0
00195     try:    # instance method?
00196         name = func.im_class.__name__ + '.' + func.__name__
00197     except: # ordinary function
00198         try:
00199             name = func.__name__
00200         except:
00201             name = ''
00202     print '%s %s (%d calls): elapsed=%g, CPU=%g' % \
00203           (comment, name, repetitions, elapsed_time, cpu_time)
00204     return cpu_time/float(repetitions)
00205 
00206 
00207 def timer_system(command, comment=''):
00208     """
00209     Run an os.system(command) statement and measure the CPU time.
00210     With os.system, the CPU time is registered as the user and
00211     system time of child processes.
00212 
00213     Note: there might be some overhead in the timing compared to
00214     running time in the OS instead.
00215     """
00216     t0 = os.times()
00217     failure = os.system(command)
00218     t1 = os.times()
00219     # some programs return nonzero even when they work (grep, for inst.)
00220     if failure:
00221         print 'Note: os.system(%s) failed' % command, 'returned', failure
00222     cpu_time = t1[2]-t0[2] + t1[3]-t0[3]
00223     print '%s system command: "%s": elapsed=%g CPU=%g' % \
00224           (comment, command, t1[4]-t0[4], cpu_time)
00225     return cpu_time

00228 def findprograms(programs, searchlibs=[], write_message=False):
00229     """
00230     Given a list of programs (programs), find the full path
00231     of each program and return a dictionary with the program
00232     name as key and the full path as value. The value is None
00233     if the program is not found.
00234 
00235     The program list can either be a list/tuple or a
00236     dictionary (in the latter case, the keys are the programs
00237     and the values are explanations of the programs).
00238     If write_message is true, the function writes a message
00239     if a program is not found. In that case, None is returned
00240     if not all programs are found.
00241 
00242     A single program can also be given as first argument. In that
00243     case, findprograms returns True or False according to whether
00244     the program is found or not.
00245     
00246     Example on usage:
00247 
00248     if findprograms('plotmtv'):
00249         os.system('plotmtv ...')
00250 
00251     # write a message if a program is not found:
00252     if findprograms(['plotmtv'], write_message=True):
00253         os.system('plotmtv ...')
00254 
00255     programs = ['gs', 'convert']
00256     path = findprograms(programs)
00257     if path['gs']:
00258         os.system('gs ...')
00259     if path['convert']:
00260         os.system('convert ...')
00261 
00262     programs = { 'gs' : 'Ghostscript: file format conversions',
00263                  'convert' : 'File format conversion from ImageMagick',
00264                }
00265     if not findprograms(programs, write_message=True):
00266         print 'the mentioned programs need to be installed'
00267         sys.exit(1)
00268     """
00269     def program_exists(fullpath):
00270         if sys.platform.startswith('win'):
00271             # add .exe or .bat to program filename:
00272             if os.path.isfile(fullpath+'.exe') or \
00273                os.path.isfile(fullpath+'.bat'):
00274                 return True
00275         elif os.name == 'posix': # Unix
00276             if os.path.isfile(fullpath):
00277                 return True
00278         else:
00279             raise TypeError, \
00280                   'platform %s/%s not supported' % \
00281                   (sys.platform, os.name)
00282         return False # otherwise
00283         
00284     path = os.environ['PATH']  # /usr/bin:/usr/local/bin:/usr/X11/bin
00285     paths = re.split(os.pathsep, path)
00286     fullpaths = {}
00287     if isinstance(programs, str):
00288         program = programs
00289         for dir in paths:
00290             if os.path.isdir(dir): # skip non-existing directories
00291                 fullpath = os.path.join(dir,program)
00292                 if program_exists(fullpath):
00293                     return True
00294         # else, not found:
00295         if write_message:
00296             print 'program %s not found' % programs
00297         return False
00298 
00299     elif isinstance(programs, (list,tuple)):
00300         # initialize with None:
00301         for program in programs:  fullpaths[program] = None
00302         for program in programs:
00303             for dir in paths:
00304                 if os.path.isdir(dir): # skip non-existing directories
00305                     fullpath = os.path.join(dir,program)
00306                     if program_exists(fullpath):
00307                         fullpaths[program] = fullpath
00308                         break  # stop when the program is found
00309 
00310     elif isinstance(programs, dict):
00311         # initialize with None:
00312         for program in programs.keys():  fullpaths[program] = None
00313         for program in programs.keys():
00314             for dir in paths:
00315                 if os.path.isdir(dir): # skip non-existing directories
00316                     fullpath = os.path.join(dir,program)
00317                     if program_exists(fullpath):
00318                         fullpaths[program] = fullpath
00319                         break
00320         
00321     if write_message:
00322         missing = False
00323         for program in fullpaths.keys():
00324             if not fullpaths[program]:
00325                 if isinstance(program, dict):
00326                     print "program '%s' (%s) not found" % \
00327                           (program,programs[program])
00328                 else:  # list or tuple
00329                     print 'program "%s" not found' % program
00330                 missing = True
00331         if missing:
00332             return None
00333         
00334     return fullpaths

00337 def pathsearch(programs=[], modules=[], where=0):
00338     """
00339     Given a list of programs (programs) and modules (modules),
00340     search for these programs and modules in the directories
00341     in the PATH and PYTHONPATH environment variables, respectively.
00342     Check that each directory has read and write access too.
00343     The function is useful for checking that PATH and PYTHONPATH
00344     are appropriately set in CGI scripts.
00345     """
00346 
00347     path = os.environ['PATH']  # /usr/bin:/usr/local/bin:/usr/X11/bin
00348     paths = re.split(os.pathsep, path)
00349     for program in programs:
00350         found = 0
00351         for dir in paths:
00352             if os.path.isdir(dir): # skip non-existing directories
00353                 # check read and execute access in this directory:
00354                 if not os.access(dir, os.R_OK | os.X_OK):
00355                     print dir, 'does not have read/execute access'
00356                     sys.exit(1)
00357                 fullpath = os.path.join(dir,program)
00358                 if os.path.isfile(fullpath):
00359                     found = 1
00360                     if where:
00361                         print program, 'found in', dir
00362                     break
00363         if not found:
00364             print "The program '%s' was not found" % program
00365             print 'PATH contains the directories\n','\n'.join(paths)
00366 
00367     path = os.environ['PYTHONPATH']
00368     paths = re.split(os.pathsep, path)
00369     for module in modules:
00370         found = 0
00371         for dir in paths:
00372             if os.path.isdir(dir): # skip non-existing directories
00373                 # check read and execute access in this directory:
00374                 if not os.access(dir, os.R_OK | os.X_OK):
00375                     print dir, 'does not have read/execute access'
00376                     sys.exit(1)
00377                 fullpath = os.path.join(dir,module) + '.py'
00378                 if os.path.isfile(fullpath):
00379                     found = 1
00380                     if where:
00381                         print module, 'found in', dir
00382                     break
00383         if not found:
00384             print "The module '%s' was not found" % module
00385             print 'PYTHONPATH contains the directories\n',\
00386             '\n'.join(paths)

00389 def pow_eff(a,b, powfunc=math.pow):
00390     """
00391     Returns a^b. Smart function that happened to be slower
00392     than a straight math.pow.
00393     """
00394     if b == 2:
00395         return a*a
00396     elif b == 3:
00397         return a*a
00398     elif b == 4:
00399         h = a*a
00400         return h*h
00401     elif b == 1:
00402         return a
00403     elif abs(b) < 1.0E-15:  # x^0 ?
00404         return 1.0
00405     elif a == 0.0:
00406         return 0.0
00407     else:
00408         # check if b is integer:
00409         bi = int(b)
00410         if bi == b:
00411             r = 1
00412             for i in range(bi):
00413                 r *= a
00414             return r
00415         else:
00416             if a < 0:
00417                 raise ValueError, 'pow(a,b) with a=%g<0'
00418             else:
00419                 return powfunc(a, b)
00420 
00421     
00422 def lines2paragraphs(lines):
00423     """
00424     Return a list of paragraphs from a list of lines
00425     (normally holding the lines in a file).
00426     """
00427     p = []             # list of paragraphs to be returned
00428     firstline = 0      # first line in a paragraph
00429     currentline = 0    # current line in the file
00430     lines.insert(len(lines), '\n') # needed to get the last paragraph
00431     for line in lines:
00432         # for each new blank line, join lines from firstline
00433         # to currentline to a string defining a new paragraph:
00434         #if re.search(r'^\s*$', line):  # blank line?
00435         if line.isspace():  # blank line?
00436             if currentline > firstline:
00437                 p.append(''.join(lines[firstline:currentline+1]))
00438                 #print 'paragraph from line',firstline,'to',currentline
00439             # new paragraph starts from the next line:
00440             firstline = currentline+1  
00441         currentline += 1
00442     return p
00443 
00444 
00445 def oneline(infile, outfile):
00446     """
00447     Transform all paragraphs in infile (filename) to one-line strings
00448     and write the result to outfile (filename).
00449     """
00450     fi = open(infile, 'r')
00451     pp = lines2paragraphs(fi.readlines())
00452     fo = open(outfile, 'w')
00453     for p in pp:
00454         line = ' '.join(p.split('\n')) + '\n\n'
00455         fo.write(line)
00456     fi.close()
00457     fo.close()
00458 
00459 
00460 def wrap(infile, outfile, linewidth=70):
00461     """
00462     Read infile (filename) and format the text such that each line is
00463     not longer than linewidth. Write result to outfile (filename).
00464     """
00465     fi = open(infile, 'r')
00466     fo = open(outfile, 'w')
00467     # the use of textwrap must be done paragraph by paragraph:
00468     from textwrap import wrap
00469     pp = lines2paragraphs(fi.readlines())
00470     for p in pp:
00471         #print 'paragraph:\n  "%s"' % p
00472         lines = wrap(p, linewidth)
00473         #print 'lines:\n', lines
00474         for line in lines:
00475             fo.write(line + '\n')
00476         fo.write('\n')
00477     fi.close()
00478     fo.close()

00481 def fontscheme1(root):
00482     """Alternative font scheme for Tkinter-based widgets."""

00487     root.option_add('*Menu*Font', pulldown_font)

00534 def movefiles(files, destdir, confirm=True, verbose=True, copy=True):
00535     """
00536     Move a set of files to a a destination directory tree,
00537     but let the original complete path be reflected in the
00538     destination tree.
00539 
00540     files         list of filenames
00541     destdir       root of destination directory tree
00542     confirm       let the user confirm movement of each file
00543     verbose       write out the original and new path of each file
00544     copy          True: copy, False: move
00545 
00546     The function is useful for backing up or temporarily moving
00547     files; the files are easily restored in their original
00548     locations since the original complete path is maintained in
00549     the destination directory tree.
00550     """
00551     if not os.path.isdir(destdir):
00552         os.mkdir(destdir)
00553     for file in files:
00554         perform_action = 'y'
00555         if confirm:
00556             print 'move %s to %s?' % (file, destdir)
00557             perform_action = sys.stdin.readline().strip()
00558         if perform_action in ('y', 'Y', 'yes', 'YES'):
00559             fullpath = os.path.abspath(file)
00560             # remove initial / (Unix) or C:\ (Windows):
00561             if sys.platform.startswith('win'):
00562                 fullpath = fullpath[3:]
00563             else:  # Unix
00564                 fullpath = fullpath[1:]
00565             newpath = os.path.join(destdir, fullpath)
00566             newdir = os.path.dirname(newpath)
00567             if not os.path.isdir(newdir): os.makedirs(newdir)
00568             shutil.copy2(file, newpath)
00569             if os.path.isfile(newpath):
00570                 print 'fount',newpath
00571             s = 'copied'
00572             if not copy:  # pure move
00573                 os.remove(file); s = 'moved'
00574             if verbose:
00575                 print s, file, 'to', newpath
00576

00578 def debugregex(pattern, string):
00579     "debugging of regular expressions: write the match and the groups"
00580     s = "does '" + pattern + "' match '" + string + "'?\n"
00581     match = re.search(pattern, string)
00582     if match:
00583         s += string[:match.start()] + '[' + \
00584              string[match.start():match.end()] + \
00585              ']' + string[match.end():]
00586         if len(match.groups()) > 0:
00587             for i in range(len(match.groups())):
00588                 s += '\ngroup %d: [%s]' % (i+1,match.groups()[i])
00589     else:
00590         s += 'No match'
00591     return s

00595 def dump(obj, hide_nonpublic=True):
00596     """
00597     Inspect an object obj by the dir function.
00598     This function first prints the repr(obj) of the object,
00599     then all data attributes and their values are
00600     listed, and finally a line listing all functions/methods
00601     is printed.
00602     """
00603     print '\n', '*'*60, '\n'
00604     try:  # dump class name if it exists
00605         print 'object of class', obj.__class__.__name__
00606     except:
00607         pass
00608     try:
00609         print 'object with name %s' % obj.__name__
00610     except:
00611         pass
00612     methods = [];  attrs = []
00613     for a in dir(obj):
00614         if a.startswith('_') and hide_nonpublic:
00615             pass
00616         else:
00617             try:
00618                 s = a + '=' + str(getattr(obj,a))
00619                 if s.find(' method ') != -1 or \
00620                    s.find('function ') != -1 or \
00621                    s.find('method-wrapper ') != -1 or \
00622                    s.find('ufunc ') != -1:
00623                     methods.append(a) # skip function addresses
00624                 else:
00625                     s += '  ' + str(type(eval('obj.'+a)))
00626                     attrs.append(s)  # variable=value
00627             except Exception, msg:
00628                 pass
00629     print '******** attributes:\n', '\n'.join(attrs)
00630     print '\n******** methods:\n', '\n'.join(methods)
00631     print '*'*60, '\n\n\n', 
00632 
00633 
00634 
00635 class BackgroundCommand(threading.Thread):
00636     """
00637     Run a function call with assignment in the background.
00638     Useful for putting time-consuming calculations/graphics
00639     in the background in an interactive Python shell.
00640 
00641     >>> b=BG('f', g.gridloop, 'sin(x*y)-exp(-x*y)')
00642     >>> b.start()
00643     running gridloop('sin(x*y)-exp(-x*y)',) in a thread
00644     >>> # continue with other interactive tasks
00645     >>> b.finished
00646     True
00647     >>> b.f  # result of function call
00648     """
00649 
00650     def __init__(self, result='result', func=None, args=[], kwargs={}):
00651         self.resultresult = result
00652         self.__dict__[self.resultresult] = None
00653         self.funcfunc = func
00654         self.argsargs = args
00655         self.kwargskwargs = kwargs
00656         self.finishedfinished = False
00657         threading.Thread.__init__(self)
00658     def run(self):
00659         kw = [key+'='+self.kwargskwargs[key] for key in self.kwargskwargs]
00660         cmd = '%s=%s(%s,%s)' % (self.resultresult, self.funcfunc.__name__,
00661                                 ','.join(self.argsargs), ','.join(kw))
00662         print 'running %s in a thread' % cmd
00663         self.__dict__[self.resultresult] = self.funcfunc(*self.argsargs,**self.kwargskwargs)
00664         self.finishedfinished = True
00665         print cmd, 'finished'
00666 
00667 BG = BackgroundCommand  # short form
00668 
00669 class Download(threading.Thread):
00670     def __init__(self, url, filename):
00671         self.urlurl = url;  self.filenamefilename = filename
00672         threading.Thread.__init__(self)
00673     def run(self):
00674         print 'Fetching', self.urlurl
00675         urllib.urlretrieve(self.urlurl, self.filenamefilename)
00676         print self.filenamefilename, 'is downloaded'

00696     # corresponding loops and scalar evaluations
00697     raise Exception, 'NOT IMPLEMENTED YET'

00700 def memusage(_proc_pid_stat = '/proc/%s/stat'%(os.getpid())):
00701     """
00702     Return virtual memory size in bytes of the running python.
00703     Copied from the SciPy package (scipy_test.testing.py).
00704     """
00705     try:
00706         f=open(_proc_pid_stat,'r')
00707         l = f.readline().split(' ')
00708         f.close()
00709         return int(l[22])
00710     except:
00711         return
00712 
00713 
00714 def _test_memusage(narrays=100, m=1000):
00715     """
00716     Test the memusage function for monitoring the memory usage.
00717     Generate narrays arrays of size (m,m). Keep the array
00718     with probability 0.5, otherwise delete a previously
00719     allocated array.
00720     """
00721     import random, Numeric
00722     random.seed(12)
00723     refs = []
00724     for i in range(narrays):
00725         a = Numeric.zeros((m,m), Numeric.Float)
00726         if random.random() > 0.5:
00727             refs.append(a)
00728         elif len(refs) > 0:
00729             del refs[0]
00730         mu = memusage()/1000000.0
00731         print 'memory usage: %.2fMb' % mu
00732 
00733 
00734 def isiterable(data):
00735     """Returns true of data is iterable, else False."""
00736     try:
00737         iter(data)
00738     except TypeError:
00739         return False
00740     return True
00741 
00742 def flatten(nested_data):
00743     """
00744     Return a flattened iterator over nested_data.
00745 
00746     >>> nested_list = [[1,2],3,[4,5,6,[7,[8,9]]]]
00747     >>> flat = [e for e in flatten(nested_list)]
00748     >>> flat
00749     [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9]
00750 
00751     (Minor adjustment of code by Goncalo Rodrigues, see
00752     http://aspn.activestate.com/ASPN/Mail/Message/python-tutor/2302348)
00753     """
00754     it = iter(nested_data)
00755     for e in it:
00756         # note: strings are bad because, when iterated they return 
00757         # strings, leading to an infinite loop
00758         if isiterable(e) and not isinstance(e, basestring):
00759             # recurse into iterators
00760             for f in flatten(e):
00761                 yield f
00762         else:
00763             yield e
00764

00767 def f(a, b, max=1.2, min=2.2):  # some function
00768     print 'a=%g, b=%g, max=%g, min=%g' % (a,b,max,min)

00775     except:
00776         pass

00778     if task == 'Command':
00779         c = Command(f, 2.3, 2.1, max=0, min=-1.2)
00780         print 'Command.args=',c.args,'Command.kwargs=',c.kwargs
00781         c()         # call f(2.3, 2.1, 0, -1.2)
00782     elif task == 'debugregex':
00783         r = r'<(.*?)>'
00784         s = '<r1>is a tag</r1> and <s1>s1</s1> is too.'
00785         print debugregex(r,s)
00786         print debugregex(r'(\d+\.\d*)','a= 51.243 and b =1.45')
